moves.1. d4 d5 2. e3: Not a great fan of this move as it is passive and blocks in the dark-squared bishop.
moves.5. Nc3 e6 6. Bd2 Nbd7 7. Qe2 Be7 8. g4: An aggressive break that justifies f3.
moves.8... Bg6 9. O-O-O c5 10. dxc5 Bxd3 11. Q: I thought that white's position was getting dangerous here.
moves.13... Nxa4 14. Qxa4 Qc7 15. Ne2 O-O: And black has a comfortable position out of the opening.  It will take white time to prepare g5 or h4, and black can look forward to pressure along the semi-open c-file.
moves.16. Nd4 a6: I didn't want the knight coming to b5.
moves.17. e4 Bc5 18. exd5 exd5: And black is left with this isolated d-pawn.  It looks like it may be difficult to defend, and I have to decide whether to try to hold on to it, and for how long.
moves.20. Qb3 Qf4+ 21. Kb1: Black is gaining the initiative.  It seems to be a critical position in the development of the game.  Will black be able to find some classy moves?
moves.21... Bxd4 22. Bxd4 Nc4 23. Qc3 f6 24. B: And I think black is a bit better, with the active rook and nice knight c4.
moves.25. Rxd5: I didn't mind this because the knight was still defended, and there are more important considerations in the position than material.
moves.25... Rac8 26. Rf5 Nd2+ 27. Ka1 Qc4: This I would have to call a very classy move, preparing for Re2 after the queens come off.
moves.30. Rc1: Defending c2, but what is white doing about the threat of Rce8?
moves.31... Re2e1: And its going to  be all over for white.
